stream_context.summary: Kaze struggles with Blender/Fast64 pipeline regressions (notably Fast64 repo settings like "write all"/"bleed" affecting exports), tests an N64-style Fast64 renderer to improve viewport performance, and continues overworld/volcano environment work (UVs/materials). He shares project status updates: Course 7 is mostly finished and out for beta test on real N64; adds a new post-star "return to overworld" dialog; discusses ROM size constraints (~60MB of 64MB), planned overworld streaming sprint, and brainstorms side-level structure and Luigi’s potential role (possibly co-op).
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains several concrete production updates (Course 7 beta on real hardware, new exit-course UX, ROM size estimate), a pipeline issue that explains recurring export bugs, and forward-looking overworld/streaming timeline plus Luigi/co-op teasing.

findings.summary: A Fast64 repo setting (“write all”) kept re-enabling itself on file reload via stored JSON repo settings, causing repeated export breakage; disabling/removing it from repo settings stopped the auto-reset and resolved at least one visible export issue (Mario’s hair disappearing).
findings.quote: No wonder I kept getting bugs. It’s because that turns itself on over and over.

findings.summary: Fast64 installation method mattered: installing the add-on via Blender’s “Install from Disk” with the zip worked, while manually extracting into the add-ons folder did not behave as expected in his setup.
The team is still blocked by a known Fast64 issue: model “switch options” beyond the base option remain broken; the attempted change did not fix the eye/switch-option issue.
findings.quote: Switch options… are still broken for sure, guaranteed 100%.

findings.summary: Course 7 is mostly finished and has been sent out for beta testing; Kaze reports it “fully works on real N64,” which is a key validation point for the project’s real-hardware target.
findings.quote: I finished most of Course 7 and I set it out for a beta test… It fully works on real N64, which is amazing.

findings.summary: Kaze implemented a quality-of-life feature after collecting a star: a prompt to either stay in the level or return to the overworld, addressing awkward flow in earlier demos where players were forced to remain in the course.
findings.quote: Do you want to return to the overworld? Stay or leave?

findings.summary: ROM budget is actively tracked against the N64’s 64MB limit: current estimated ROM size is 59.953 MB, leaving little headroom and implying careful asset/content management for the remainder of development.

Overworld production plan: keep an initial connected but visually-rough pass, then later consolidate it into “one big level” that loads dynamically while walking, to support cross-visibility (e.g., large trees seen from multiple angles) without fighting current forest/visibility constraints.
findings.quote: After your pass is done, I'm going to make this all into one big level that loads dynamically as you walk through it.

findings.summary: Kaze notes bug fixing is unusually heavy because the engine has been rewritten multiple times, creating cascading regressions and compatibility issues across systems/assets.
findings.quote: Bug fixing is a lot of work for a hack of this size, especially because we rewrote the engine so many times.

findings.summary: A specialized N64-style Fast64 renderer significantly improved Blender responsiveness (near 0% CPU in his test) but showed inaccuracies in transparent decal/depth behavior compared to in-game results, suggesting it’s useful for workflow speed but not fully faithful for validation.

Side-level structure brainstorming: an “oil tanker” infiltration concept tied to boss progression/side-level unlocking (mentions “5 bosses” and a warp to “Oily Body Bay”), with an intent to keep side levels small and fast to build (1–2 days each).
Short-term schedule expectation: Kaze expects a two-week streaming burst during upcoming time off work and believes the overworld could be finished in that window (at least to a first-pass state).
findings.quote: In two weeks, I’ll be off work… We will probably finish the overworld in those two weeks.

findings.summary: Kaze is trying to drive the codebase toward “zero compile warnings,” fixing warnings opportunistically as they appear.

biobak.summary: Biobak is encouraged to try the new Fast64/N64-style renderer as well, implying the tool could benefit other artists working on RTYI assets.

findings.summary: Lilaa helps diagnose that the troublesome “write all” behavior is stored in Fast64’s repo settings JSON and suggests turning off auto node repo settings / adjusting repo settings rather than per-file tweaks; her guidance leads Kaze to remove/disable the setting so it no longer re-enables on reload.
Lilaa points Kaze toward installing add-ons via Blender’s “Install from Disk” method and introduces/advocates the Fast64 renderer option that improves Blender performance on Kaze’s machine.
“Pack normals” support is discussed as contingent on Sauraen’s continued involvement, highlighting a dependency on specialized N64 graphics/renderer expertise outside Kaze’s core work.
findings.quote: If Sauraen gets struck by lightning tomorrow, then we probably will never have them.

key_stories.title: Fast64 repo setting regression caused repeated export bugs
key_stories.summary: Kaze investigates why exports keep breaking and notices a Fast64 option (“write all”) re-enables itself when reopening the blend file due to being stored in repo-level JSON settings. This manifests as confusing visual issues (e.g., Mario’s hair disappearing) and undermines confidence in recent tool changes.
key_stories.challenge: A workflow-breaking setting keeps resetting, producing inconsistent exports and making it hard to attribute bugs to user error vs. Fast64 changes/PRs.
key_stories.process: Kaze tests toggling “write all”/“bleed,” confirms the setting auto-resets on reload, then removes/disables the line in repo settings and verifies the behavior no longer returns.
key_stories.outcome: The auto-reset stops and the immediate symptom (missing hair) is resolved, but other Fast64 issues (switch options/eye rendering) remain unsolved, leaving ongoing tooling risk.
key_stories.key_quote: No wonder I kept getting bugs. It’s because that turns itself on over and over.

key_stories.title: Improving post-star flow with an exit-to-overworld prompt
key_stories.summary: Kaze shows a new dialog that appears after collecting a star, allowing the player to either stay in the level or return to the overworld. He frames it as a fix for awkward pacing in earlier builds where players were stuck in-course after collecting a star.
key_stories.challenge: Earlier demo behavior disrupted the gameplay loop by not offering a clean return path to the hub/overworld.
key_stories.process: He implements a dialog choice (stay/leave) and demonstrates it in-game during the stream.
key_stories.outcome: A more polished, player-friendly loop that better matches expectations from Mario 64-style progression while supporting RTYI’s custom overworld structure.
key_stories.key_quote: Do you want to return to the overworld? Stay or leave?

open_questions.context: Kaze imports Luigi, calls him the stream’s “special guest,” and says co-op would be the coolest option, but he’s unsure how Luigi will tie into RTYI yet.
questions: Was Luigi added for true co-op gameplay, an unlockable character, story/credits stinger, or a technical experiment?
If co-op is planned, what are the biggest engine constraints (camera, netcode/local input, object syncing, performance on real N64) and what’s the minimum viable co-op feature?
If co-op is not feasible, what alternative use of Luigi best serves the game (postgame content, parallel challenges, assist mode, etc.)?

open_questions.context: Kaze plans to keep a rough connected overworld first, then rebuild it as a single large level with dynamic loading to handle cross-visibility and avoid forest/occlusion pain.
questions: What technical approach will be used for dynamic loading on N64 (area streaming, segmented memory, custom object/geo loading)?
What content needs to be visible across boundaries (trees, landmarks, skybox elements), and how will LOD/occlusion be handled?
When does the team decide the ‘first pass’ is good enough to begin the dynamic-loading rebuild?

open_questions.topic: Fast64 reliability and the remaining ‘switch options’ breakage
open_questions.context: Even after addressing the repo-setting reset, Kaze states switch options beyond the base option remain broken and the attempted fix didn’t resolve the eye/switch issue.
questions: What exactly is broken in Fast64 switch options (material overrides, display list branching, palette/indexed textures, or export ordering)?
What’s the current workaround for affected assets, and how many models are blocked by this?
Is the plan to pin to a known-good Fast64 version for production, or continue tracking main and absorbing breakages?
Which changes would Kaze want upstreamed to prevent similar repo-setting ‘auto reset’ problems?

open_questions.topic: Using the N64-style Fast64 renderer in production
open_questions.context: The renderer dramatically improved Blender performance but showed inaccuracies with transparent decals/depth quantization compared to in-game visuals.
questions: Will the renderer be adopted as the default tool for artists despite fidelity issues, or only for performance troubleshooting?
What specific rendering mismatches matter for RTYI art direction (decals, transparency sorting, clip planes, depth precision), and how will they be validated?
Who will maintain/extend this renderer for RTYI needs, and how does it integrate with the asset export pipeline?

open_questions.topic: ROM size headroom and content planning
open_questions.context: Kaze reports an estimated ROM size of 59.953 MB out of 64 MB and mentions a very high final music track count estimate (~120).
questions: What categories are the biggest ROM consumers right now (textures, music, level geometry, cutscenes)?
What’s the contingency plan if the project exceeds 64MB (asset compression changes, cutting content, multi-ROM approach, or streaming from cartridge hardware assumptions)?
How is music being stored/handled to support ~120 tracks within the memory/ROM budget?
